title: Why you feed in lane
body:
-When your opponents push, you try and push them back before your minions get there.
-You forget that your ward has gone off cooldown and get ganked in a really bad position.
-When you and your lane partner creep up lane you don't realize that getting surrounded by minions is a bad thing, get cc'd and engaged.
-you play aggressively before your damage spikes up and flat yourself out before you do any real impact.
-you focus too hard on suppressing and killing your opponent that you don't get minions. Late game nightmare.
-You roam before securing an objective, your lane opponent gets fed.

You miss your ult

replies.body:
Although a lot of these thing may seem obvious to yourself, many players struggle to access the strategy level of this game.
I think this post could be very helpful if you wrote it as a tutorial "How not to feed in your lane", and explain the logic behind these points.

For instance;
> -When your opponents push, you try and push them back before your minions get there.
 Why is it important to keep the minions in the centre of the lane?
Are there advantages to freezing elsewhere?
Are there disadvantage to being pushed?

If you keep all criticism constructive it will result in a better game experience for everyone!

Honestly it was just that, criticism. It's crap I see so often in games that i'm going off in chat saying "how did you think that was a good idea?". Now i'm not perfect but we should all just stop for a moment to let common sense take control and wonder what is the wisest option to consider rather then just waiting for your opponents next misstep as a sign to go take the kill, when not considering cs, objectives, possible ganks for both their team and yours and objective control (sounds that same as objectives but is slightly different)... this is not a game to flex our ego's and flaunt our kill scores like a rich man flaunts $100 notes.

I get it's frustrating, but I repeat what is obvious to you, is not transparent to others.
It's also hard to explain and teach in game so I get your frustration.
But if you made a set of instruction in a new post or a youtube video, you can add players after a game, and recommend the video.
Keep it friendly, "Hey I noticed to made a few obvious and avoidable mistakes I lane, and I believe your performance could really improve if you followed this advice" and insert the link.
It's a good idea, im doing year 12 at the moment so my plate is a bit full but I will look into doing this

I'm in my 6th year of uni, so i totally get the work/play balance struggle. 

Prehaps it could even be a forum post like this.  I'm curious to hear your reasoning behind some of these so that tactics can be discussed.
This entire post could be so much more constructive.There's good potential, but I advise revising your approach and delivery.
